name: Tunis
fun_fact: Fun fact: Harissa - the fiery chili paste now famous worldwide - actually originated in Tunisia! In 2022, harissa's knowledge, skills, and culinary practices were inscribed on UNESCO's Intangible Cultural Heritage list. And Tunis sits next to ancient Carthage, with ruins dating to 1000 B.C.!

hero_dishes.name: Brik √† l'≈íuf
hero_dishes.description: Delicate pastry filled with tuna, egg, and herbs, fried to golden crispy perfection with a runny egg inside
hero_dishes.origin_story: Thought to date back to the Ottoman Empire, brik is now ubiquitous Tunisian street food. The goal with your first bite is to find the runny egg and drink the juices! Crispy outside, oozing with flavor inside - a beloved appetizer and street food favorite.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: El Ali (rustic medina location with cultural heritage and panoramic views), nearly any fast food stand around Tunisia, street markets in the Medina of Tunis

hero_dishes.name: Couscous (Kosksi)
hero_dishes.description: Tunisia's national treasure - spicier than other North African versions, with tender lamb, fish, or chicken cooked with vegetables in fragrant cumin, coriander, and harissa sauce
hero_dishes.origin_story: Unlike its North African neighbors, Tunisian couscous is based on tomato sauce (not turmeric) and almost never contains fruits (raisins being rare exception). The traditional way is with meat, vegetables, and chickpeas. Expect VERY large portions!
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Dar Belhadj (famous couscous au lamb with tender meat and aromatic spices, candlelit ambiance with intricately tiled walls), El Ali (couscous au poisson - hearty seafood version), La SafSaf in La Marsa (8-10 TND average cost)

hero_dishes.name: Lablabi
hero_dishes.description: Rustic chickpea stew flavored with garlic, cumin, and olive oil, served with crusty bread and a poached egg
hero_dishes.origin_story: A beloved street food and breakfast dish representing Tunisia's resourceful, flavorful cuisine. The warming chickpea stew is comfort food at its finest.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street vendors and caf√©s throughout Tunis medina, especially popular for breakfast

hero_dishes.name: Mechouia Salad
hero_dishes.description: Grilled vegetable salad with tomatoes, peppers, and onions, dressed with olive oil and spices
hero_dishes.origin_story: A classic Tunisian starter showcasing Mediterranean influences blended with North African spices
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Fondouk El Attarine (beautifully restored medina building), traditional Tunisian restaurants

hero_dishes.name: Fresh Seafood
hero_dishes.description: Catch of the day, simply grilled and perfectly cooked
hero_dishes.origin_story: Tunisia's Mediterranean coastline provides exceptional fresh seafood, grilled with simple but flavorful accompaniments
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Chez Slah (unassuming seafood institution on quiet street, reputation draws diners from everywhere), Le Golfe (fine dining with Mediterranean Sea views)

signature_drinks.description: Sweet mint tea often topped with toasted pine nuts or almonds
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Flows through daily life as a symbol of hospitality! Similar to Moroccan tea but often topped with pine nuts or almonds for extra flavor. Usually pre-mixed with sugar and can be very sweet. Tunisia has deep-rooted caf√© culture where men and women gather to socialize, drink mint tea with pine nuts, and discuss politics or football.

signature_drinks.name: Tunisian Wine
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Available at restaurants and wine bars, pairing with Mediterranean-influenced Tunisian cuisine

food_culture_notes: Tunisian cuisine reflects crossroads of civilizations: Arabic, Berber, Mediterranean, and French influences
Harissa (fiery chili paste with garlic, olive oil, spices) is a culinary cornerstone - UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage!
Brik eating technique: Find the runny egg with your first bite and drink the juices
Couscous portions are VERY large - come hungry!
Deep-rooted caf√© culture: gathering in public spaces for mint tea, socializing, politics, football discussions
Carry cash (Tunisian dinars) - cards may not be accepted in small shops
Learning a few French or Arabic phrases helps for daily interactions
The Medina of Tunis (UNESCO-listed) offers bustling street markets with spices, produce, local delicacies
Carthage International Festival brings world performers to Roman amphitheatre - music, theatre, dance under stars
